qas.question: Along with the Renaissance, during what period were the Middle Ages disparaged?
What era did Renaissance scholars negatively compare the Middle Ages to?
How did scholars of the Enlightenment see the Middle Ages?

answers.text: as a time of ignorance and superstition

qas.question: What did Enlightenment scholars consider to be inferior to reason?

context: The medieval period is frequently caricatured as a "time of ignorance and superstition" that placed "the word of religious authorities over personal experience and rational activity." This is a legacy from both the Renaissance and <a0_0>Enlightenment<a0_0/>, when scholars contrasted their intellectual cultures with those of the medieval period, to the detriment of the Middle Ages. Renaissance scholars saw the Middle Ages as a period of decline from the high culture and civilisation of <a1_0>the Classical world<a1_0/>; Enlightenment scholars saw reason as superior to <a3_0>faith<a3_0/>, and thus viewed the Middle Ages <a2_0>as a time of ignorance and superstition<a2_0/>.
